data.question: What is the effect of crystal downsizing on the structural flexibility of coordination frameworks?
data.answer: Crystal downsizing regulates the structural flexibility of coordination frameworks and induces a shape-memory effect, where a metastable open dried phase can be isolated when the crystals are downsized to the mesoscale.

data.question: How does the crystal size of [Cu2(bdc)2(bpy)]n affect its sorption properties?
data.answer: As the crystal size decreases, the gate-opening pressure shifts to a higher value, indicating that the crystal size controls the framework flexibility and the sorption properties.

data.question: What are the two structural phases observed in [Cu2(bdc)2(bpy)]n crystals after guest removal, and how does their formation depend on crystal size?
data.answer: After guest removal, [Cu2(bdc)2(bpy)]n crystals exhibit either a nonporous closed phase or a metastable open dried phase. The formation of the open dried phase is favored in smaller, meso-sized crystals.

data.question: Can the open dried phase of [Cu2(bdc)2(bpy)]n be converted back to the closed phase, and if so, how?
data.answer: Yes, the open dried phase of [Cu2(bdc)2(bpy)]n can be converted back to the closed phase through thermal treatment.

data.question: What role does crystal downsizing play in the stabilization of the open dried phase in [Cu2(bdc)2(bpy)]n?
data.answer: Crystal downsizing suppresses the structural mobility, stabilizing the open dried phase by potentially increasing the surface enthalpy contribution and/or enhancing kinetic suppression of the phase transition.

data.question: How does the crystal size of [Cu2(bdc)2(bpe)]n influence its ability to undergo a reversible phase transition between the open dried and closed phases?
data.answer: In [Cu2(bdc)2(bpe)]n, as the crystal size decreases, the ability to undergo a reversible phase transition between the open dried and closed phases is initially enhanced, but further downsizing to below 300 nm results in a rigid framework that cannot transition back to the closed phase.

data.question: Is the open dried phase of [Cu2(bdc)2(bpy)]n observed in both micrometer-sized and meso-sized crystals?
data.answer: The open dried phase of [Cu2(bdc)2(bpy)]n is primarily observed in meso-sized crystals, whereas micrometer-sized crystals tend to revert to the closed phase after guest removal.

data.question: Does the sorption behavior of [Cu2(bdc)2(bpy)]n change after converting the open dried phase to the closed phase through thermal treatment?
data.answer: Yes, after converting the open dried phase to the closed phase through thermal treatment, [Cu2(bdc)2(bpy)]n exhibits gate-type sorption behavior, which is different from the type I uptake observed in the open dried phase.

data.question: True or False: The structural transformation from the open dried phase to the closed phase in [Cu2(bdc)2(bpy)]n is irreversible.
data.answer: False

data.question: True or False: Crystal downsizing always results in a decrease in the gate-opening pressure for sorption in [Cu2(bdc)2(bpy)]n.
data.answer: False

data.question: True or False: The open dried phase of [Cu2(bdc)2(bpy)]n can be regenerated after converting it to the closed phase and then performing complete desorption.
data.answer: True

data.question: True or False: The sorption properties of [Cu2(bdc)2(bpy)]n are independent of its crystal size.
data.answer: False

data.question: True or False: The open dried phase of [Cu2(bdc)2(bpy)]n exhibits gate-type sorption behavior similar to the closed phase.
data.answer: False

data.question: True or False: The stabilization of the open dried phase in [Cu2(bdc)2(bpy)]n is solely due to thermodynamic factors.
data.answer: False

data.question: True or False: The adsorption capacity of the open dried phase of [Cu2(bdc)2(bpy)]n changes after multiple cycles of reversible phase transformation.
data.answer: False

data.question: What is the relationship between the crystal size of [Cu2(bdc)2(bpy)]n and the gate-opening pressure in its sorption isotherms?
data.answer: As the crystal size of [Cu2(bdc)2(bpy)]n decreases, the gate-opening pressure in its sorption isotherms shifts to a higher value.

data.question: How does the sorption behavior of the open dried phase of [Cu2(bdc)2(bpy)]n compare to that of its closed phase?
data.answer: The open dried phase of [Cu2(bdc)2(bpy)]n exhibits type I uptake without gate-type sorption behavior, whereas the closed phase shows gate-type sorption behavior.

data.question: What mechanism is proposed for the kinetic suppression of phase transition in downsized crystals of [Cu2(bdc)2(bpy)]n?
data.answer: The kinetic suppression of phase transition in downsized crystals of [Cu2(bdc)2(bpy)]n is attributed to a decrease in the number of lattice defects, which serve as nucleation sites, leading to enhanced kinetic suppression.

data.question: What experimental technique was used to confirm the identity of structural phases in [Cu2(bdc)2(bpy)]n crystals?
data.answer: Single-crystal x-ray diffraction (XRD) was used to confirm the identity of structural phases in [Cu2(bdc)2(bpy)]n crystals.

data.question: Can the sorption properties of [Cu2(bdc)2(bpy)]n be switched between two distinct states, and if so, how?
data.answer: Yes, the sorption properties of [Cu2(bdc)2(bpy)]n can be switched between two distinct states by converting the open dried phase to the closed phase through thermal treatment and vice versa through solvent-mediated structural transformation.
